title: HALESTORM’S LZZY HALE Says Upcoming Record Is "The Most HALESTORM Record" They've Made
description: Apparently, the ADHD was ADHD'ing in the studio, and it ended up being a real good thing. The post HALESTORM’S LZZY HALE Says Upcoming Record Is "The Most HALESTORM Record" They've Made appeared first on Metal Injection.
author: Isabella Ambrosio
byline: By Isabella Ambrosio Published 6 hours ago
excerpt: Apparently, the ADHD was ADHD'ing in the studio, and it ended up being a real good thing.
text: It's been almost three years since Halestorm released their 2022 record, Back From The Dead. So, every avid music fan knows – music is on the horizon. And, frontwoman Lzzy Hale confirms that the band was "getting mixes back," when talking on Cutter's Rockcast. Working with Grammy-awarded producer Dave Cobb, known for his work with Greta Van Fleet, Rival Sons, and Slash, Halestorm explained that they felt that "his ADHD mixed very well with [the band's] ADHD." A much less organised, but still very cathartic process, Hale feels as if there are "a lot of personalities that [she's] always wanted to kind of put on a record, but [she] never really had the freedom or time to…" Tapping into that idea, Hale describes that there are "some of the heaviest songs [they've] ever written on there," alongside "some really beautiful mid-tempos." Most of all, it feels completely authentic, "There's nothing on this album that anybody forced [them] to do. There's nothing on this album that isn't part of [their] personalities." "The music was telling [them] what to do and not [them] trying to like shoehorn anything in," Hale explains. For "the first time in 20 years," "it is the most Halestorm record [they've] ever done," the Halestorm frontwoman said on the podcast. html:
It's been almost three years since Halestorm released their 2022 record, Back From The Dead. So, every avid music fan knows – music is on the horizon. And, frontwoman Lzzy Hale confirms that the band was "getting mixes back," when talking on Cutter's Rockcast.

Working with Grammy-awarded producer Dave Cobb, known for his work with Greta Van Fleet, Rival Sons, and Slash, Halestorm explained that they felt that "his ADHD mixed very well with [the band's] ADHD." A much less organised, but still very cathartic process, Hale feels as if there are "a lot of personalities that [she's] always wanted to kind of put on a record, but [she] never really had the freedom or time to…"

Tapping into that idea, Hale describes that there are "some of the heaviest songs [they've] ever written on there," alongside "some really beautiful mid-tempos." Most of all, it feels completely authentic, "There's nothing on this album that anybody forced [them] to do. There's nothing on this album that isn't part of [their] personalities."

"The music was telling [them] what to do and not [them] trying to like shoehorn anything in," Hale explains.

For "the first time in 20 years," "it is the most Halestorm record [they've] ever done," the Halestorm frontwoman said on the podcast.
